channel.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News: TOI brings the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Fearing Awami League comeback, BNP seeks Jamaat support to halt Hasina
item.description: BNP is seeking support from Jamaat-e-Islami to prevent the Awami League from regaining power in Bangladesh. This move follows the ouster of Sheikh Hasina and claims of her call for armed resistance. Meanwhile, Awami League plans to resume political activities and street protests against the interim government led by Muhammad Yunus.

item.title: No new limits on Ukraine's use of US arms if North Korea joins fight: Pentagon
item.description: The US will not impose new limits on Ukraine's use of American weapons amid North Korean military deployments to Russia. NATO's Mark Rutte and the Pentagon have raised concerns about 10,000 North Korean troops in eastern Russia, potentially supporting combat operations against Ukraine near the border.

item.title: Want more peace deals with Arab nations after war: Bibi
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expresses hope of finalizing peace treaties with additional Arab nations once current conflicts with Hamas and Hezbollah are resolved. Emphasizing ongoing plans, Netanyahu seeks to build on the Abraham Accords and secure a stable, prosperous Middle East, highlighting ongoing negotiations for a Gaza ceasefire and hostage deal.

item.title: Iranian-German prisoner Jamshid Sharmahd, who lived in US, executed in Iran over terror conviction
item.description: Iranian-German prisoner Jamshid Sharmahd, abducted by Iranian security forces in Dubai in 2020, has been executed in Iran. Convicted on terror charges, including planning a 2008 mosque attack, Sharmahd's family disputes the allegations and had strived for his release. He was captured after a mysterious journey from Dubai to Oman.

item.title: Harris says crude and racist rhetoric at Trump's event fans the fuel of division
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris condemned former President Donald Trump's rally at Madison Square Garden, stating that it perpetuated division and hatred. Harris emphasized that Trump's focus on grievances and divisive rhetoric does not support the aspirations of the American people.

item.title: Netanyahu says Iran strives for nuclear bomb 'stockpile' to destroy Israel
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has accused Iran of building a nuclear arsenal aimed at Israel's destruction. This comes after Israel bombed Iranian military sites in retaliation for an earlier attack by Tehran, escalating tensions and prompting a warning from Iran of firm retaliation.

item.title: In video: UK MP's viral footage of punching man gets him suspended
item.description: Labour Party MP Mike Amesbury has been suspended after CCTV footage showed him punching a man. Amesbury claimed he felt threatened during the incident. He reported the altercation to Cheshire Police and will cooperate with their investigation. Amesbury has represented Cheshire since 2017 and was previously a shadow minister.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: British far-right activist 'Tommy Robinson' jailed for violating injunction
item.description: Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, known as Tommy Robinson, received an 18-month prison sentence for contempt of court after breaching an injunction related to a libel lawsuit by Syrian refugee Jamal Hijazi. Robinson repeatedly violated the court's order during YouTube interviews and a documentary. His past offenses include assault, contempt of court, and mortgage fraud.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Japan PM blames election outcome on public's 'suspicion and mistrust' over scandal
item.description: Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba acknowledges the LDP's election setback caused by public distrust over a funding scandal. Despite losing the majority, Ishiba plans to lead a minority government, dismisses coalition formation, and aims to restore faith through political reform and open discussions.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Thai court drops case over deaths of Muslim protesters in 2004
item.description: A court in southern Thailand dropped charges against ex-state security personnel and officials over the 2004 Tak Bai massacre, where 85 Muslim protesters died. The court attributed the decision to the suspects evading arrest, causing the 20-year statute of limitations to expire. Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra apologized, vowing to prevent future incidents.

item.title: Ukraine says detains local WFP volunteer for aiding Russia
item.description: Kyiv has arrested a Ukrainian man volunteering with the UN's World Food Programme for allegedly providing intelligence to Russian forces in the Pokrovsk sector. He is accused of identifying Ukrainian military positions for targeted drone and artillery strikes, facing life in prison on high-treason charges.

item.title: Pakistan begins another vaccination campaign after a worrying surge in polio cases
item.description: Pakistan initiated a nationwide campaign to vaccinate 45 million children against polio after a recent surge in cases. Despite violence targeting health workers, the government is committed to eradication efforts, urging full cooperation from parents. Pakistan and Afghanistan remain the only two countries where polio continues to spread due to under-vaccination.

item.title: Japan PM vows to stay on despite election debacle
item.description: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba pledged to remain in office despite his Liberal Democratic Party's (LDP) worst result in 15 years, losing its ruling majority due to a slush fund scandal. Voters' mistrust and anger significantly impacted the election, seeing the opposition gain considerable ground.

item.title: US elections: Latin superstar Bad Bunny endorses Kamala Harris for President
item.description: Bad Bunny endorses Kamala Harris for the 2024 US Presidential election. He shared a video emphasising the importance of Puerto Rican voters. This endorsement follows offensive comments made about Puerto Rico at a Trump rally. With significant Puerto Rican voters in Pennsylvania, Bad Bunny’s support may boost Harris’s appeal among Latino voters.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'It barely exists anymore': How Russia transformed Ukrainian city Vovchansk into a ghost town
item.description: The Russia-Ukraine war has devastated the eastern regions of Donetsk and Donbas, with the industrial town of Vovchansk nearly destroyed. Civilians face harsh conditions, and familial bonds are fracturing along political lines. Despite severe sanctions, Russia's economy endures, largely due to oil trade with India and China.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Kamala broke it, I'll fix it': Trump leads Madison Square Garden rally as Election Day looms
item.description: Trump held a New York rally, criticising Kamala Harris and pledging to fix issues he claims she created. Familiar themes included immigration and tariffs. High-profile speakers like Elon Musk and Tucker Carlson attended. Controversial remarks, especially from Tony Hinchcliffe, added tension. Harris simultaneously campaigned in Philadelphia, addressing Puerto Rican support.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: At least 40 killed in attack on Chad military base
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Once ruling campuses, over 50k student members of Sheikh Hasina's party now in hiding
item.description: On October 23, the leader of the Bangladeshi interim government led by Muhammad Yunus banned BCL terming it a "terrorist organisation". According to Bangladesh's home ministry, the BCL had a history of serious misconduct over the past 15 years, including violence, harassment and exploitation of public resources, Al Jazeera reported.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Insults, offensive jokes and racist comments: MAGA speakers attack Kamala Harris from Madison Square Garden
item.description: At a Trump rally in New York City, several MAGA speakers, including Sid Rosenberg and David Rem, made racist and inflammatory remarks about illegal immigrants and Vice President Kamala Harris. Comedian Tony Hinchcliffe also made a controversial comment about Puerto Rico, drawing criticism from Harris' campaign.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Watch: Harris supporter yells into a young girl's face
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
